Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

Oilers fan Scott Kaufmann @ScottKaufmann7

I think if he put a few more pucks in the net that it could be excellent value. B+

Oilers fan Jarod Okemow @okemow_jarod

450k too much but it’s ok.. McDavid will take less ..AGAIN

Oilers fan Jake @OilAcumen

Too much money IMO. Player goes from a value deal to an overpay at that number, even with a rising cap.

My take

A year ago we couldn’t spell his name. Now he’s something of a folk hero in Edmonton.

I’m good with this deal, even as Podkolzin didn’t score much last season. The deal presents a risk, but it’s a solid bet on a useful player who has already proven he can make an impact as a second or third line winger.

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

Why get fired up about Edmonton signing such a player? As wrote earlier this summer in assessing Podkolzin, he brings many qualities that the Oilers need, namely youth, hitting, durability, hitting, hard work, more hitting, dedication, and even more hitting.

Such is his prowess at the physical game, which includes the ability to win pucks through aggressive forechecking and backchecking, that Draisaitl was reportedly satisfied to play with him through the year, which is no small accomplishment.

If we rank NHL forwards by their rates of goal scoring, assisting on goals and hitting at even strength for the 2024 and 2025 playoff season, giving equal weight to each of the three categories, Podkolzin ranks as the top forward in the NHL.

NHL power forwards 5-on-5 play 2024 and 2025 playoffs, minimum 10 games played, 177 qualifying forwards

He made the most of limited ice-time, just 10.1 minutes per game at 5-on-5. He found a way to help out on scoring players while delivering 25.6 hits per 60 at 5-on-5, the fifth highest of any forward in the last two playoff years.

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

Of course this is a small sample size, and if we do a similar ranking for the entire 2024-25 regular season, Podkolzin ranks just 246th out of all regular NHL fowards due to his unexceptional goals and assists rates.

But we can see that if he can just pick up his offensive game a bit, he’ll be a very useful power forward for years to come, one that can hold his own in a Top 9 slot, if not playing in the Top 6.

More evidence of Podkolzin’s worth? At the Cult of Hockey video review project, we track hard plays that Oilers players make on Grade A shots, the goalie screens, hard charges, battles won, tips and jams that lead to Grade A shots and goals.

In the regular season, Podkolzin was the second best Oiler — after the superlative Zach Hyman — at executing such hard plays to create dangerous shots on net.

In 82 games, Podkolzin executed eight goalie screens, seven tip shots, 14 jam shots, five hard charges or drives on net, and won 31 battles leading to Grade A shots, 65 hard plays on Grade A shots in total, 0.79 per game, behind Hyman at 1.64 per game and just ahead of the increasingly frisky and mean Ryan Nugent-Hopkins at 0.78 per game.

In the playoffs this year, Podkolzin’s rate of hard plays at the net on Grade A shots dropped off to 11 in 22 games, just 0.50 per games, but he also get less ice time and less opportunity with Draisaitl.

In the playoffs, Corey Perry went beast-mode, as did RNH, both of them increasing their rates of such hard plays from the regular season, but Perry is gone now, off to Los Angeles, as is Evander Kane, a true hard man of hockey, but now a Vancouver Canuck.

The grit and ferocity of both Kane and Perry will be missed.

One hopes that Trent Frederic, who was pretty much a non-factor in the 2025 playoffs when it came to making hard plays to create Grade A shots (just three in 22 games) will be much, much, much better this coming season with improved fitness and health. Frederic will be counted on to bring much of what Edmonton lost with Perry and Kane departing.

But Podkolzin will also be a key for Edmonton this coming year.

Is there risk in such a deal? Yes.

Maybe the extra point scoring never materializes and he can’t cut it on a skill line over time.

Maybe you’re stuck paying more over the long term for a bottom line player. There is risk here, but I’m comfortable enough with Podzilla’s game to endorse this move.

Edmonton is short on what he brings. What he brings can help win Stanley Cups.

title: Blue Jays hoping for 'best version' of Anthony Santander while parting ways with Alek Manoah
text:
In there was any shot of Anthony Santander being a part of the Blue Jays’ post-season plans, it was beginning to feel like more of a long shot of even getting into game action this week.

Until it wasn’t.

And Alek Manoah’s return to the big leagues with Toronto? Forget about it after the Jays designated the big righty for assignment.

“It was a very tough, very difficult decision,” Jays general manager Ross Atkins said of parting ways with his former first-round pick. “This just came down to a roster crunch, and a feeling (it was) the best decision … as we push forward in very important weeks.”

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

It certainly was perceived as a wild bombshell of an announcement by the team less than an hour prior to Tuesday’s big game against the Boston Red Sox, as the Jays announced that Santander would be activated for the contest, this after sitting out 100 games with a shoulder ailment. The Manoah move was made to clear a roster spot for Santander but certainly spoke volumes at how it felt about Manoah’s performance while recovering from Tommy John surgery.

In another transaction, first baseman Ty France was placed on the injured list with left oblique inflammation.

Toronto Blue Jays’ Anthony Santander runs to first base after his single off Tampa Bay Rays pitcher Garrett Cleavinger during the sixth inning of a baseball game Saturday, May 24, 2025, in Tampa, Fla.

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

Atkins said he spoke with Manoah personally, not an easy call obviously, but one the team felt it needed to make.

“He worked extremely hard, really impressed by his dedication to coming off Tommy John,” Atkins said of Manoah, who was third in American Cy Young Award voting after a terrific 2022 season. “He was disappointed. We wish him the best.”

Manoah, who has missed more than a year while recuperating from elbow surgery, can now be claimed by any other MLB team now that he’s on waivers. The 11th overall pick of the 2019 draft could elect to pursue free agency should he go unclaimed.

When Schneider spoke shortly before 4 p.m., he said the team hoped to have an answer regarding Santander’s status by Wednesday. With the Manoah decision made, the team suddenly swerved to get the big hitter, who signed a five-year, $92.5-million US deal in the off-season, back in action. Santander wasn’t in the starting lineup against the Red Sox, but activated.

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

“He looked like himself,” Atkins said when asked what impressed about Santander’s at-bats in a rehab assignment in triple A. “And then I think there will be another gear, with that adrenaline coming into the fold here.”

Meanwhile, Schneider said that the other big hitter the team hopes to have in action come playoff time — that being shortstop Bo Bichette — continues to make progress.

Schneider said that Bichette, who has missed 15 games with what the team is describing as a knee sprain, was hitting in the cage on Monday at the Rogers Centre and had “probably one of the best days so far” since sustaining the injury in a crash at home plate at Yankee Stadium.

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

Bichette was hitting in the cage again on Tuesday but has yet to resume running.

“We’ll continue to take it one day at a time,” Schneider said. “The recovery part has been as we expected but it’s going to take time for him to feel more and more comfortable and kind of letting it go a little bit.

“He’s still got to get back in the routine of swinging. He has a very deliberate routine in the cage. It’s getting that back first and making sure you feel okay and then kind of letting it eat a little bit.”

RECOMMENDED VIDEO

title: Maple Leafs goalie Joseph Woll taking leave of absence - what it means for Toronto
text:
Joseph Woll has taken a leave of absence from the Maple Leafs.

The Leafs announced on Tuesday that the 27-year-old goaltender will be away from the team to attend to a personal family matter.

“There is no timeline (for Woll’s return),” Leafs general manager Brad Treliving said. “We obviously support him 100% and I would just ask that everybody respect his privacy. We’re not going to get into a whole lot of detail on it.

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

“For context, it’s not a substance abuse issue. It’s a personal family matter that Joe is going to deal with and we will go from there.”

Treliving wouldn’t provide further detail.

“Certainly our expectation is that Joe is going to be back with us and we will see when that is,” Treliving said. “All our worry is just supporting and looking forward to getting him back.”

Treliving said he didn’t know whether Woll would be back in time for the start of the regular season. For the Leafs, that’s Oct. 8 at home against the Montreal Canadiens.

“It’s a tough situation for him,” Leafs coach Craig Berube said. “We’re all here to support him, do what we can to help. That’s really it. He needs to do what he needs to do. We’re all thinking about him. We miss him and we’re all here to support him as best we can.”

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

Said Matthew Knies: “We feel for him and we’re going to try our best to support him and give him space, let him take this on his own. We’re always there for him and wish him the best.”

WHAT WOLL’S ABSENCE MEANS

Nothing changes for Anthony Stolarz, who was in line to be the starter for the opener. He just has to continue to get himself prepared as he would had Woll not been gone.

The Leafs remain solid in net with Stolarz, who is looking to use his NHL-leading .926 save percentage last season as a springboard.

“The timing and speed of the game,” Stolarz said of his focus. “I’ll probably get in the next couple of games (Thursday in Montreal or Saturday at home against the Canadiens), so looking forward to that.

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

“Just going out there and enjoying yourself again. Being out there with the guys, battling out there again, seeing the fans. You start getting a little anxious, a little jittery, to get the games and season going.”

Will the Woll development have an impact on contract negotiations with Stolarz? We don’t think so. Stolarz has said he wants a new deal done before the regular season begins. There’s little reason for the status of Woll to change that.

The Leafs signed Dennis Hildeby to a three-year contract earlier in September and there’s confidence that he can be the backup for the time being.

“It’s up to me to earn that trust every day,” Hildeby said. “Just keep working hard. I’m a big guy. Last year, I moved a lot more than I had to in some situations, I felt like. When I feel good, it doesn’t look too hard with my size. That’s where I want to be.”

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

Treliving during the off-season didn’t sign a veteran goalie so the club could have some insurance in the wake of an injury and he won’t scour the market for one now.

But if one of Stolarz or Hildeby gets hurt? That’s where the Leafs would be in bind. Treliving would have no choice but to seek help.

“You’re always looking at your team,” Treliving said. “We just have to wait and see right now.

“We’re comfortable with the goalies we have. Our expectation is Joe is going to be back with us, but we’ll see.”

UP NEXT

Berube said Hildeby will start on Tuesday night and play a couple of periods at Scotiabank Arena as the Leafs play host to the Ottawa Senators in another pre-season Battle of Ontario.

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

Berube isn’t going with a full NHL lineup, as Easton Cowan and Ben Danford will play after impressing on Sunday afternoon in the Leafs’ 4-3 win in Ottawa. Luke Haymes also will get another look.

“I loved their games in Ottawa, both of them,” Berube said. “I thought Easton played a real direct game, did some good things. Those are the types of things I’m looking for. A young kid like that — how is he going to fit in our lineup? Can he do certain things?

“Danford has great feet. He’s very composed for a young kid, in my opinion. And he made some really nice outlet passes. He’s simple. He doesn’t get himself into trouble.”

Cowan will skate on a line with centre Scott Laughton and Steven Lorentz. Danford will be paired with Oliver Ekman-Larsson on the blue line.

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

Defenceman Simon Benoit continues to nurse an upper-body injury and was not on the ice on Tuesday, though Berube said he doesn’t think the issue was serious.

Max Domi, meanwhile, was absent as he was attending the funeral of his grandfather.

THE LEAFS LINEUP

FORWARDS

Matthew Knies-Auston Matthews-Matias Maccelli

Bobby McMann-John Tavares-William Nylander

Dakota Joshua-Luke Haymes-Nick Robertson

Steve Lorentz-Scott Laughton-Easton Cowan

DEFENCE

Jake McCabe-Chris Tanev

Morgan Rielly-Brandon Carlo

Oliver Ekman-Larsson-Ben Danford

GOALTENDERS

Dennis Hildeby

Artur Akhtyamov

tkoshan@postmedia.com

title: Blue Jays’ Kevin Gausman reveals love for this iconic B.C. beer
text:
In the past, Kevin Gausman has professed his love for Toronto and Canada in different ways.

The foodie scene. The city itself. And his fondness for the fan base.

And now, a little-known slice of his admiration for his work home that extends beyond the Ontario borders.

Gausman’s beer of choice, which per his request is well-stocked in the Blue Jays clubhouse? That would be B.C.’s own, Kokanee.

The affinity for the lager that the Creston, B.C., brewers bill as having a “glacier fresh taste” came from Gausman’s older brother, Brian, who pitched for the Kelowna Falcons back in 2006.

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

Working the mound for the West Coast League outfit, Brian Gausman finished with a 2-3 record with a 2.61 ERA while striking out 28 over 41.1 innings in 12 appearances.

The elder Gausman was there in the prospect league long enough to acquire a taste for the popular B.C. beer and pass it on to Kevin, who has been a fan ever since.

As much as the 34-year-old Jays starter appreciates many things Canadian, he’s in particular admiration of the Blue Jays team in full drive mode to become the only last-to-first-place squad in franchise history.

And Gausman, who is slated to make his 31st start of the season on Tuesday when the Jays begin their final homestand of the season with the first of three against the Boston Red Sox, thrives on the challenge ahead.

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

“I mean, this is what you, as a player, you dream of to be playing meaningful games,” Gausman said in a recent interview. “It’s fun to watch what’s going on with other teams and other races

“But it’s exciting just because of the guys we have. This team has been just so much fun. I mean 2021 was kind of the same way when I was (with the San Francisco Giants) and we won 108 games and it was a lot of no-name guys. But also superstars that kind of had resurgent years.

“That’s what we are.”

Despite the remaining stress in the pursuit of the AL East crown, the Jays current position is in stark contrast to where the team was a year ago when Gausman was as frustrated as anyone in the clubhouse and wasn’t shy about sharing his thoughts.

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

“I’m sick of the ‘talent’ talk,” Gausman said in an interview during the final week of the 2024 season. “We’re so talented, this and that. We’ve got to start winning games. We’ve got to figure it out. We’ve got to do it quickly. I’m only getting older. (Fellow starter Chris) Bassitt is only getting older. If we want it to happen with this group, it has to happen soon. So what are we going to do?”

What has happened since then, of course, has rejuvenated Gausman and his fellow veterans. With 90 wins and six games remaining, the Jays already have won 16 games more than last season with bigger prizes tantalizingly within reach.

From Gausman’s perspective, it’s exactly where he wants to be — getting the start in a huge game for a team determined to maintain its status as the best in the American League.

“I definitely appreciate this a little bit more now, you know,” Gausman said. “I don’t know how many more of these (opportunities) I’ll have. I hope next year we’re in the same boat, but you never know as a player.

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

“So yeah, just trying to soak it in and have as much fun and be the best teammate I can be on the days I’m not pitching.”

In his 13 big league seasons, Gausman has seen plenty of highs and lows — from last-place teams to starting for the Giants in the National League Championship Series. All the more reason, then, to be soaking up what’s happening with the Jays now.

“I think we’re just a really close-knit group that we don’t really feel too much pressure,” Gausman said. “We just kind of try to win the day and these guys have been resilient all year. They seem to know when to say, ‘All right, we need to take it to another level.’

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

“It’s been fun to watch guys take the next step. It takes being here the last couple of years to kind of see the big picture. Hats off to the organization for taking the next step as well when it comes to personnel.”

His final start of the 2025 season on Tuesday obviously is a big one, only to be topped by what happens in what will be his ninth post-season appearance.

“It’s go time,” Gausman said. “If you love sports, this is the best time of year. It’s going to be fun from here on in.”

All the better to enjoy with an ice-cold B.C. brew.

title: Ontario mother wins lottery twice in one year after striking $60M jackpot with coworkers, $250K solo
text:
Trang Pham of Mississauga, Ont., has had a year most lottery players can only imagine. After splitting a $60-million Lotto Max jackpot with four co-workers in January, the mother of two has now claimed another life-changing prize — $250,000 from an Instant Golden Multiplier ticket (Game #2449).

“It’s unbelievable! It feels like I was struck by lightning twice in one year. You have to give yourself a smack just to make sure it’s real!” said Pham, who could hardly believe she was back at the OLG Prize Centre so soon.

A long-time lottery player, Pham has been playing with OLG since she turned 18. Over the years, she has tried her hand at everything from Lotto Max and Lotto 6/49 to Daily Grand and a range of Instant tickets.

This most recent win happened almost by accident.

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

“I was shopping at an outlet mall and got thirsty, so I stopped at a nearby gas station to grab a bottle of water,” said Pham, who purchased her winning ticket at Petro-Canada on Steeles Avenue West in Hornby, Ont.

“While I was there, I ended up buying a couple of tickets.”

The next morning, sitting in her car, she decided to scratch her Golden Multiplier ticket.

“I uncovered the top prize and realized it was a winning ticket,” she said. “Then I scanned it using the OLG app on my phone — and there it was: $250,000! I was so happy and excited.”

Moments later, she called her husband to share the incredible news. “His response was, ‘Really?’ He was surprised and overjoyed,” said Pham, who also told a few friends about her astonishing win.

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

“They were also shocked but thrilled for me at the same time.”

What makes the win even more remarkable is that this isn’t Pham’s first jackpot of the year. In January, she and four colleagues from a construction company matched all seven numbers in the Jan. 21, 2025 Lotto Max draw, making them the winners of a $60-million prize. Pham, who had been part of the workplace pool for years, said the life-changing windfall was almost impossible to believe.

Now, just months later, she’s experiencing the thrill of winning again — but this time on her own. With her $250,000 prize, Pham says she’ll cover some bills and indulge in some well-deserved travel.

Instant Golden Multiplier is a $10 ticket with a top prize of $250,000. Players scratch to match their numbers to the lucky numbers, with multipliers that can boost the prize up to five times. There are also extra games on the ticket where three matching symbols give players another win.

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

Overall odds of winning any prize are 1 in 3.40, making Pham’s second jackpot this year feel all the more surreal.

If you're looking to take a break from gambling, self-exclusion programs can be effective tools. See here for resources that are available across Canada.

title: Barry Appleton: Canada's 'hopium' U.S. trade strategy all talk, no troops
text:
Canada just announced consultations for the Canada-United States-Mexico (CUSMA) trade agreement, copying America’s homework while forgetting we don’t have the same tools to complete the assignment. It’s like showing up to a gunfight with a strongly-worded letter.

Here’s the stark reality: The United States has over 700 trade experts on standby, ready to defend their interests. Canada? Zero. We dismantled our Sectoral Advisory Groups on International Trade (SAGITs) in 2013 to save pennies. Now we’re paying in billions.

As an international trade lawyer who has testified twice before U.S. trade authorities this year — with a third appearance likely — I can tell you firsthand: we’re not just outgunned, we’re not even in the fight.

The consultation charade

Yes, Canada needs consultations. But consultations without strategy are just expensive focus groups. The U.S. has a mandatory consultation process backed by deep expert advisory bodies that actually shape policy. The U.S. shares drafts being negotiated and the experts enhance the U.S. negotiators’ abilities in realtime. Their system works because it’s built on substance, not symbolism.

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

Meanwhile, Canada’s approach amounts to what I call “hopium” — the delusional belief that good intentions and polite dialogue will somehow protect our $3.6-billion daily trade relationship. We can smoke all the hopium we want, but it’s our economy getting smoked.

Time and again, we enter negotiations hoping for the best and getting the worst. Then we act surprised when we get steamrolled.

The missing army

This is not about bureaucratic infrastructure. It is about economic survival. We have world-class expertise in energy, critical minerals, digital innovation, financial technology, quantum computing and cross-border services sitting idle. These aren’t random volunteers; these are battle-tested professionals who understand the chess game of international trade.

Yet Ottawa hasn’t even asked for their help.

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

We’re facing economic hostilities — let’s call them what they are — and our government won’t mobilize the very experts who could defend our interests. It’s organizational malpractice on a national scale.

Consider our recent humiliations: When Washington demanded Canada withdraw the collection of its Digital Services Tax, Ottawa folded within hours. When Meta blocked Canadian news, we had no countermeasure. These weren’t tactical defeats; they were strategic surrenders that exposed what happens when you enter negotiations without a plan.

Beyond denial

U.S. Ambassador Pete Hoekstra recently stated that strengthening the trading partnership is a priority — but make no mistake, this means strengthening it on America’s terms. The Americans are laser-focused on protecting their interests, sector by sector, provision by provision. They’re playing hardball while we’re still looking for our glove.

The Trump administration’s transactional aggression has started to become institutionalized. And why wouldn’t it continue? It’s working for them.

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

Meanwhile, Canada clings to the fantasy that our “special relationship” will shield us from economic reality. There are no friends in trade negotiations, only interests. Trade with the U.S. isn’t marriage therapy — there’s no monogamy here, only hard power.

The path forward

Here’s what Canada must do, starting yesterday:

• First, immediately reconstitute our trade advisory infrastructure. Not after more consultations — now. Every day we delay, Canadian businesses lose market share and Canadian workers their jobs.

• Second, develop an actual strategy before launching consultations. Define our objectives, identify our leverage points, and determine our red lines. Then consult on tactics, not fundamentals.

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

• Third, mobilize sectoral experts immediately. We need to create formal advisory committees for a large number of areas — including energy, critical minerals, automotive, agriculture, intellectual property and digital trade. Give them security clearances, real influence, and direct access to negotiators.

• Fourth, stop treating trade policy as public relations. This isn’t about announcements; it’s about results. Every empty press release weakens our position.

• Fifth, acknowledge that we’re in an economic battle and act accordingly. Co-ordinate with provinces, industries and unions as if our economic future depends on it — because it does.

The bottom line

The CUSMA review clock is already ticking. The Americans aren’t waiting for us to get our act together. Every day we spend on performative consultations instead of substantive preparation is a day our competitors gain ground.

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

Canada’s economy is one-tenth the size of America’s. Without strategy, size dictates outcomes. We cannot afford to negotiate from weakness, yet that’s exactly what we’re doing — entering every negotiation under-resourced, unprepared, and hoping goodwill will save us.

The question isn’t whether we can afford to resource our trade strategy properly. The question is whether we can afford not to.

Right now, while we’re holding consultations about consultations, America is eating our lunch. And they’re using our own trade agreement to do it.

It’s time to stop the hopium and face reality: Canada needs to wake up, mobilize its expertise, and design a plan for the future — before the U.S. dictates one for us.

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

Because in this relationship, power is the only currency that matters. And unless Canada stops hoping and starts planning, we’ll keep getting smoked.

National Post

Barry Appleton is an international trade lawyer, Distinguished Senior Fellow and co-director at the Center for International Law at New York Law School, and a scholar and Fellow at the Balsillie School of International Affairs.

title: Canucks: Joe LaBate is the Everyman every fan should know
text:
There is 100 per cent one thing left to do on Joe LaBate’s professional hockey to-do list: score a goal in the NHL.

“Yes, absolutely,” he says with a knowing smile, his eyes lighting up as well. And, yes, he’s come home.

“Oh yeah man, full circle,” he laughed about signing with the Canucks seven years after he left. “They feel like the right fit. They’ve got some openings and they need what I bring. Some grit. Some sandpaper.”

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

He’s not a name that jumps off the page, and he’s likely headed for Abbotsford to start the season. But there’s little doubt that if he does make it back to Rogers Arena, he’ll quickly remind everyone why he was a bit of a cult figure in his first NHL go-round with the Canucks, nine seasons ago.

In a career that’s seen it all, that’s one thing that stands out about LaBate. He’s long known the value of hard work and of knowing your role.

Long ago he worked his tail off to make the NHL. Along the way he suffered a near-career-ending hip injury in the AHL. He also learned to be a fighter, figuring that would help him stay in the league.

Kraken centre John Hayden and Joseph LaBate of the Canucks scrap in the first period on Sunday in Seattle.

Then he spent eight years away from the show, including a season in the KHL. A season in Russia for a team that won 14 games — but at least he got to be a first line centre for a bit.

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

Wait, what?

“That was really fun,” he recalled, of his one season playing for Barys Astana in Kazakhstan. The team wasn’t good, but he got to play a ton and experience the world.

To say the 32-year-old LaBate has been around the block and is more than happy to be back where it all started is a bit of an understatement. The Canucks drafted the 6-foot-5 Minnesotan in 2011. Then he spent four years playing collegiate hockey with the University of Wisconsin before beginning to chase the NHL dream in 2015. It took him just over a season to make it to the NHL: 13 games over three call-ups for Willie Desjardins’ Canucks in 2016-17.

He didn’t pick up a point but he did drop the globes and skate his tail off. It’s the wheels that got him to the NHL.

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

And then near disaster struck. A hip injury in February 2018 nearly ended his career.

“You’re right there, trying to make yourself into an everyday NHLer, and then your body just fails and you got to kind of climb back,” he said, looking back at the hip injury. “And it makes you realize how quick things can change. It turned me into an everyday, very detailed professional. And I’ve grown a lot from it.”

Joe Labate (62) in the middle of the action against the Calgary Flames during third period 2016 NHL Young Stars Classic action at the South Okanagan Events Centre in Penticton.

But he found his way back to health and signed on with the Belleville Senators. He played three years there, then started to bounce around a little: a season in Milwaukee, then one with the Chicago Wolves. Then he tried out Kazakh cuisine.

“I got to play 20 minutes a night. First line centre. Power play,” he said of his time with Astana. “That was really good for me.”

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

Then the Columbus Blue Jackets came calling, looking for exactly what the Canucks are looking for this year: a guy who has some miles on his resume, who knows the meaning of everyday professional.

His hard-working season earned him a late season call-up and six more games in the NHL.

“I just love hockey. I’m obsessed with it. I love the chase,” he said. “I think it was 2,886 days between games? It was pretty special to get back in it.”

He admitted to having some tears in his eyes when he got the call last spring. He called his fiancée Clara, then his parents. He got to play for a team that was dealing with all kinds of emotional trauma, but one that found unity in the wake of the Johnny Gaudreau tragedy.

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

“It was obviously a very hard year. But I think as an organization, as a group, everyone came together, and it made them stronger. Once I got there. Everyone was super welcoming,” he said.

For the record it was 2,888 days between games, but that’s impressively close enough. And in a sport where the word “special” gets overused, this was a very good use of the word.

Special, indeed.

And now he’s back where it started. He’s playing for a team run by Ryan Johnson, a guy he’s known since he was just a prospect. Johnson was hired by the Canucks to work as a development coach in 2013, when LaBate was starting his third year at Wisconsin. And now-Abbotsford head coach Manny Malhotra was in his first season as a development coach when LaBate made his NHL debut. He’s pumped to work with the defending Calder Cup champion.

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

“I know he’s a phenomenal coach, so that’s a huge plus. And then obviously the organization as a whole, you know, the Sedins are here; I used to play with them! RJ and me, we go way back. Yeah, a lot of ties here. So it just felt right.”

And yeah, he wants to get that first NHL goal.

pjohnston@postmedia.com

title: Premier Danielle Smith wants a fast track for Alberta teacher training
text:
Premier Danielle Smith wants Alberta's education and advanced education ministers to create an "abbreviated" teacher training program for people who already have post-secondary credentials.

She's also tasked Education and Childcare Minister Demetrios Nicolaides with negotiating a new federal-provincial child-care agreement.

In her mandate letters to Nicolaides and Advanced Education Minister Myles McDougall, Smith instructs the ministers to develop a teaching certification program for people with training in "relevant fields" that doesn't require an education degree.

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

"The real goal here is to help get individuals that have some expertise in any industry, in any field and … help them to qualify to teach and bring their wisdom, their experience and their knowledge into the classroom in a much faster manner," Nicolaides said in an interview on Monday.

The move would be a departure from the current requirement for Alberta classroom teachers to have a minimum of four years of university education, including a teacher training preparation program.

An existing "bridge-to-teacher" program that enables skilled tradespeople, health professionals and information technologists to teach with an interim certificate while completing teacher training coursework takes too long and has low uptake, Nicolaides said.

Nicolaides' press secretary, Garrett Koehler, said 113 people have received provincial grants to complete the bridge program in the last five years.

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

Nicolaides said an abbreviated teaching credential would only allow the person to teach in their area of expertise. Questions about pay and whether other provinces would recognize the credential have yet to be worked out, he said.

The program should be ready before the next provincial election, scheduled for Oct. 18, 2027, he said.

ATA says move undermines teachers' skills

Although creating a shorter program was in Nicolaides' previous mandate letter, Alberta Teachers' Association (ATA) president Jason Schilling said he is concerned to see the goal remains.

"We don't want to find an expedited teaching certificate process that undermines the profession and the quality of teachers that we're seeing in our schools," he said.

Alberta Teachers' Association president Jason Schilling says teachers need more skills to succeed in K-12 classrooms than the government seems to think. (Nathan Gross/CBC)

Schilling said teachers in training learn how to interpret curriculum, instruct, assess and manage students, work with students who have exceptional needs, and complete a practicum of in-classroom experience.

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

He said understanding how to teach isn't the same as having subject matter expertise.

Schilling said legal changes would be needed to create different categories of teacher certification. He has questions about how such instructors would be paid and how their wages and working conditions would be bargained.

"We're pointing these things out to government — that it's just not as easy as they think it is," he said.

Bradley Lafortune, executive director of Public Interest Alberta, says lowering the bar for teacher certification could decrease the quality of teaching in the province. He said deprofessionalizing teachers could be a move toward a more American system, where teachers are paid less.

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

"I think it's a slap in the face to the profession," Lafortune said.

Renewed emphasis on trades

Smith's mandate letter also repeated previous education goals, including creating more avenues for junior and senior high school students to be exposed to skilled trades careers.

Smith asked Nicolaides to design and implement a high-school apprenticeship system, advertise trades careers to teens, launch an online career counselling website and invest in more mobile career and technology studies (CTS) labs.

Alberta's premier wants to see schools create more pathways for students to enter trades careers. (Submitted by Build a Dream)

Nicolaides is also tasked with reviewing, assessing and better supporting K-12 students with complex needs. The proportion of students with disabilities, medical needs, mental health challenges or who are learning English is increasing in Alberta schools.

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

The minister said he doesn't have a timeline or a format yet for that review. Nicolaides said he wants to explore whether his ministry can work together with health and social services to serve students more efficiently.

Daycare deal expires in March 2026

Nicolaides is the third minister since Smith became premier in October 2022 to work with Ottawa on a federal-provincial deal to make child care more affordable.

Alberta's $3.8-billion agreement with the federal government is supposed to reduce the cost of care in participating centres to $10 a day by 2026.

The province has also committed to creating 68,700 new licensed child-care spaces by March 2027. The provincial government's website says that in June, Alberta had added about 67 per cent of those new spaces, but it is closer to meeting its goals in for-profit and day home centres.

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

Koehler said there are 130,000 children in licensed child-care spaces across the province, from babies to kindergarten.

The federal funding agreement with Alberta expires on April 1. Alberta is one of two provinces that has not extended the agreement by five years.

Nicolaides says officials at both levels of government have been in touch, and he has requested a meeting with his federal counterpart.

"We have notified them that we do want to see some changes, and we do want to see a little bit more flexibility," he said.

A federal-provincial agreement has subsidized participating Alberta daycares to offer an average of $15-a-day child care fees to families. (Courtney Jennings)

Smith's letter instructs Nicolaides to ink a deal that doesn't discriminate between non-profit and for-profit child-care centres when funding new spaces.

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

Child Care Now Alberta chair Susan Cake says Alberta's mixture of non-profit and for-profit child care isn't unique among the provinces, and doesn't merit special consideration.

Cake says the province is right to want more funding for the program to make child care affordable for all parents.

However, she says Alberta seems to be demanding special treatment, much like in 2021, when Jason Kenney's UCP government wanted a "no strings attached" deal.

"Unfortunately, it looks like a political fight with the federal government," Cake said. "However, it'll be Alberta families that are ultimately losing out."

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

She said the province would have a better chance of customizing the agreement if it was willing to contribute more funding.

Cake says she was disappointed to see no more child-care goals in Nicolaides' letter.

She wants the government to prioritize creating more child-care spaces in "deserts" where care is hard to find, and to offer more training for early childhood educators, as well as collecting data on daycare demands across the province.

title: John Ivison: The Liberals' easiest days may be behind them
text:
Mark Carney has long maintained that “a plan beats no plan” and in his speech to the Council of Foreign Relations in New York on Monday, he outlined his strategy for middle power survival in the new era of great power rivalry.

He said Canada has what the world wants — clean energy like LNG; five of the top 10 critical minerals; 40 per cent of the world’s listed mining companies; some of the best AI, computing and quantum talent found globally; capital, in the form of sophisticated pension funds; and a federal government with the fiscal capacity to act.

He conceded that much of the brain power drains south to the U.S., as does much of the capital (only a quarter of the total assets of Canada’s Maple Eight pension funds is invested at home).

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

But he said Canada still offers people and businesses values to which most of the world still aspire. “We’re a pluralistic society that works… Our public square is loud, diverse and free,” he said, taking a not-so-subtle dig at an America where the law and natural justice seem to be splintering in different directions.

The Canadian government recognizes what is going on, he said — a rupture in international relations — and is building resilience at home by cutting taxes, diversifying trade relations, removing barriers to interprovincial trade, fast-tracking large infrastructure projects, making efforts to double the rate of housing construction, and doubling defence spending by 2030.

The core capabilities in AI, quantum, cyber security and critical minerals will be developed with an eye toward dual use for defence and the economy, in line with the calls by people like U.S. economist Noah Smith to adopt industrial policy that builds up the country’s “electro-industrial stack” — a suite of core technologies needed to manufacture a wide array of products from drones to phones, using lithium ion batteries.

Yet, as Carney himself suggested in his book Value(s), voters should trust those who seek the truth but doubt those who say they have found it (quoting French writer André Gide).

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

All of these initiatives are at the inception stage, but Carney must be concerned that things are not going as smoothly as he might have hoped. As a central bank governor, he acted as a benevolent dictator, who could expect things to happen as planned when he pulled a lever. In the federal government, the levers are often not attached to anything.

As head of a minority government, he has to use cordials as well as discipline. He has to assuage progressive backbenchers and even opposition parties, given he needs three votes to pass his budget. Yet Elizabeth May, the Green leader, told Politico this week that the PMO won’t even return her emails. This is a circumstance with which many journalists will sympathize, given the Carney government seems to be adopting the Stephen Harper “off the record, no comment” playbook when it comes to the media.

Ministers and MPs have, apparently, been told to only speak when there’s something good to say, which may not be bad advice, but it is likely to burn much of the goodwill that was generated by the incoming government. Meanwhile, Pierre Poilievre is doing the rounds of the political shows, even if his “good to be here… it’s a privilege” response to CTV’s Vassy Kapelos sounded less than sincere.

The Conservative leader will have a tough time convincing Canadians that everything is worse under Carney than it was under Justin Trudeau but his line: “Let’s hold Mr. Carney to the standards he set for himself” is a winner, if things start to unravel.

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

There are storm clouds ahead for this government.

The Building and Land Development Association released Toronto new home sales figures for August that showed an 81 per cent drop on the 10-year average. This might reduce prices but it creates more inventory and reduces the incentives for homebuilders to build more homes.

The government has promised 500,000 homes a year over the next four years but BILD said it will be a stretch to keep annual housing starts in the 200,000 range. Mike Moffatt, founding director at the Missing Middle Initiative, said Ottawa’s housing numbers are looking unrealistic. “The CMHC (Canada Mortgage and Housing Corporation) has housing starts falling by four per cent a year, every year through 2027. Tough to see how we’ll double housing starts in a decade,” he said.

Regulating the housing market may be like controlling the wind. But as a government you can adjust your sails to avoid squalls in foreign policy.

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

In the case of Ottawa’s recognition of a Palestinian state, the government has navigated into the teeth of a perfect storm.

On the eve of the Jewish new year, Carney said Canada’s recognition of Palestinian statehood is consistent with this country’s policy since 1947. He said the prospect of a two-state solution is “receding before our eyes” because of the actions of the current Israeli government.

He said the move was taken alongside “a host of influential but not decisive countries” — like France, the U.K. and Australia.

It seems the motivation comes more from aligning with the Europeans in trade and security partnerships than from any conviction that this is a sound idea.

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

The normally sure-footed Carney looked less than convincing when asked at the Council of Foreign Relations event about one of the conditions for recognition — namely, the disarmament of Hamas.

“Who if not Israel will carry out the disarmament of Hamas? And if a party committed to Israel’s destruction wins Palestinian elections, won’t you in effect have granted Hamas their own state to launch more invasions of Israel?” the questioner asked.

Carney said the disarmament and elimination of Hamas as a political force is one of the conditions for the cessation of hostilities and that a combination of Arab and European states, “to which Canada would be party,” could form a multinational force to enforce the peace. It all sounded optimistic in the extreme.

Hamas proceeded to underline its humanitarian credentials by publicly executing three alleged Israeli collaborators on Monday.

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

Things are unlikely to get better for this government. A career in politics is no preparation for being a minister. Newbies are apt to step in it, as Public Safety Minister Gary Anandasangaree did this week when he was recorded saying he didn’t believe the government’s gun buyback plan would work and that it was being done to appease Quebec. Unless the PMO can instill an omertà like code of silence on the caucus and cabinet, others will follow suit.

With a budget due in early November, and nearly a third of Canadians expecting bad news, the government’s plain sailing days are over.

Were it not for the public’s unwavering approval in Carney and his plan — at least compared to Poilievre — the Liberals would be taking on more water.

jivison@criffel.ca

Twitter.com/IvisonJ

title: American travellers ‘flag jacking’ the Maple Leaf met with frosty response in Canada
text:
While U.S. president Donald Trump’s repeated comments about making Canada his country’s 51st state have raised the ire of many Canucks, news that Americans travelling abroad are now posing as Canadians will no doubt further fan the flames of discord.

While it has long been the practice of Canadians travelling abroad to affix their country’s flag on their backpack or other luggage, American media giant CNN recently reported that U.S. residents have, in recent months, “revived a decades-old practice of masquerading as Canadians in order to avoid anti-American sentiment abroad under the Trump administration. They’re hiding behind the Maple Leaf, falsely identifying themselves as Canadians and displaying the Canadian flag on their bags in a phenomenon known as flag jacking.”

The Canadian flag has long been positively received abroad, leading many Canadians to display the Maple Leaf on their luggage while travelling.

And Canadians are understandably reacting to the trend — none more so, perhaps, than Canadian cultural commentator Tod Maffin, who stated in a short video on social media: “For some reason, Americans think that we are their backup passport. The world’s first dual-action moral absolver. Just apply gently and watch the shame disappear.”

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

The news comes at a time when Canadians are already shunning travel south of the border. In fact, a July report from Statistics Canada revealed that, for the first time in five years, fewer Canadians were travelling to the U.S. than Americans making the trip to Canada.

According to the report: “In July 2025, the number of Canadian-resident return trips by automobile from the United States totalled 1.7 million, a steep decline (-36.9 per cent) from the same month in 2024.”

The report also showed that in July 2025, the number of returning Canadian-resident trips by air from the United States declined by 25.8 per cent to 383,700 from the same month one year earlier.

And Canadians aren’t the only ones shying away from travel to the U.S. According to data from the U.S. National Travel and Tourism Office, in the first seven months of the year, the number of overseas visitors, excluding travellers from Canada and Mexico, declined by more than three million, or 1.6 per cent, compared to the same period in 2024.

title: Leamington-based mushroom grower fined $115K after worker 'critically injured'
text:
A provincial court has fined a Leamington-based mushroom grower $115,000 after a worker was badly injured on the job more than two years ago.

In July 2023, an unidentified worker was "critically injured" at Highline Produce Limited's facility in Kingsville, Ont., after becoming entangled in a net that a machine was rolling and washing, according to the province.

"To be removed and reused effectively, nets had to be aligned correctly on the Net Washer so they did not shift and become entangled in either end of the machine's bar," the Ontario ministry of labour said in a press release Monday.

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

"Misalignment of the nets was a normal occurrence that required workers to adjust nets with their hands," the release said. "The worker was attempting this realignment but became entangled in the net that was threaded on the rotating bar. This resulted in a critical injury."

The ministry's investigation concluded that there "were no measures, procedures, guards or other devices in place to prevent workers from becoming entangled when adjusting nets on the machine," per the release.

Highline pleaded guilty to violating the Occupational Health and Safety Act, the province said. Last month, a justice of the peace imposed the fine as well as a 25 per cent victim surcharge, as required by law.

Highline did not immediately respond to a request for comment.

It's not the first time the company has faced penalties over serious worker injuries at its facilities. In May 2019, Highline was fined $75,000 after a worker was caught in a moving cable. Later that year, the company was fined $90,000 after a worker was caught and dragged into a conveyor.

title: Composite illustration featuring Canadian musician Sarah McLachlan, left, and U.S. talk-show host and comedian Jimmy Kimmel. Two groups of ABC affiliates, Nexstar and Sinclair, said Tuesday they will not air Jimmy Kimmel Live!, despite ABC returning it to the airwaves with McLachlan as a special guest.
text:
Composite illustration featuring Canadian musician Sarah McLachlan, left, and U.S. talk-show host and comedian Jimmy Kimmel. Two groups of ABC affiliates, Nexstar and Sinclair, said Tuesday they will not air Jimmy Kimmel Live!, despite ABC returning it to the airwaves with McLachlan as a special guest. (Sammy Kogan/The Canadian Press, Kevin Winter/Getty Images - image credit)

ABC's Jimmy Kimmel Live! is set to return to the air on Tuesday, after a nearly weeklong suspension that triggered a national discussion about freedom of speech, with Canadian musician Sarah McLachlan announced as a surprise guest.

But two groups of ABC affiliates that denounced the late-night talk show host last week said they would not carry Kimmel's return.

Nexstar Media Group — which operates 32 ABC affiliate stations in the U.S. — said it would continue to pre-empt the show, "pending assurances that all parties are committed to fostering an environment of respectful, constructive dialogue in the markets we serve."

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

Sinclair Broadcast Group — the country's largest ABC affiliate operator — also said it would keep Kimmel off its stations.

The two corporations collectively control about one-quarter of ABC affiliates in the United States. Citytv, which is owned by Rogers Communications and holds the Canadian rights to Kimmel's show, confirmed to CBC News that they will resume broadcasting it on Tuesday night.

Sarah McLachlan to perform

Actor Glen Powell was originally the sole celebrity scheduled to appear on Kimmel's Tuesday broadcast, but Sarah McLachlan posted on Instagram on Tuesday that she would be joining the show.

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

Earlier, McLachlan cancelled a performance at the U.S. premiere for her documentary Lilith Fair: Building a Mystery, which was released on Disney+ on Sept. 21, "in support of free speech." Disney is ABC's parent company.

"It's a gift for all of us to see [this documentary], but also I've grappled with being here tonight and around what to say about the present situation that we are all faced with," McLachlan said at the Ford Theater in Los Angeles on the weekend.

She referred to "the insidious erosion of women's rights, of trans and queer rights, the muzzling of free speech."

Publicists for both the Hulu-distributed documentary and the musician have confirmed she is also booked as an interview guest on Kimmel's show tonight.

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

Representatives for McLachlan noted she was already slated to appear on Kimmel's show to promote her new album, Better Broken, before the host was pulled from the air.

Also Tuesday, Kimmel made his first comments on social media since his show was pre-empted.

On Instagram, he shared a photograph of himself with writer, producer and activist Norman Lear. In a tribute to the All in the Family-creator, who died in 2023, Kimmel called him "not only a giant in the world of television, but a great man who was one of the most important and impressive people I ever had the pleasure of meeting."

Lear was outspoken against the Federal Communications Commission (FCC), a government agency tasked with regulating radio, television and internet content. Lear stated that the agency's adoption of "family viewing time" — an FCC-designated window in which programing must be suitable for all age groups — was a "deceit" and form of censorship.

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

According to the Smithsonian Magazine, Lear was on former U.S. President Richard Nixon's "enemies list" the goal of which then White House Counsel John Dean said was to "use the available federal machinery to screw our political enemies."

When Trump won his second term, Kimmel joked on-air that he was on the president's "list of enemies."

WATCH | Former FCC chairman offers his take on suspension of Jimmy Kimmel show:

ABC suspended Kimmel indefinitely after comments he made in a monologue last week, when Kimmel said the U.S. had hit "new lows over the weekend with the MAGA gang desperately trying to characterize this kid who murdered Charlie Kirk as anything other than one of them and doing everything they can to score political points from it."

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

Kimmel made similar statements in his followup show the next night.

The next day, FCC chair Brendan Carr appeared on conservative podcaster Benny Johnson's show, decrying Kimmel's words as "appearing to directly mislead the American public" about the alleged shooter's political affiliations.

"We can do this the easy way or the hard way," Carr said on the podcast, hinting that the FCC has "remedies that [they] can look at," even as market pressures that could lead to Kimmel's firing mounted.

"These companies can find ways to change conduct to take action, frankly, on Kimmel. Or, you know, there's going to be additional work for the FCC ahead."

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

Soon after, Nexstar said they would replace Jimmy Kimmel Live! with other programming. Sinclair then said they would do the same in a statement thanking Carr, before ABC announced they were pre-empting Kimmel's show entirely.

That was followed by posts by U.S. President Donald Trump on Truth Social, saying the move was "great news for America."

Debates around free speech

Some characterized Carr's involvement as government overreach. U.S. Sen. Elizabeth Warren told CNN on Thursday that "we know there was federal interference" given Carr's appearance on Johnson's podcast. Earlier, she took to X to compare ABC pre-empting Kimmel's show with Paramount cancelling Stephen Colbert — a decision they made shortly after Colbert criticized Paramount for settling a defamation case with Trump.

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

Paramount said they made the move for purely financial reasons, but were also in late stages of a merger with the company Skydance — a move the FCC could have blocked.

Warren opened an investigation in May into whether Paramount engaged in bribery with the Trump administration in order to secure the deal. Both Carr and Paramount denied the two issues were related.

Nexstar is seeking a merger with station owner Tegna, which would also require FCC approval.

"First Colbert, now Kimmel," Warren wrote Tuesday. "Last-minute settlements, secret side deals, multi-billion dollar mergers pending Donald Trump's approval."

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

In reference to Kimmel, Senate Democrats issued a statement claiming Carr "weaponized" the FCC to "act as a roving press censor, targeting broadcasters based on their political commentary."

At a New York appearance on Monday, Carr denied that the FCC had any involvement in ABC removing the show, instead citing poor ratings as the reason Kimmel "is in the situation that he's in."
